passages.text: August 28, 2025 03:00 AM GMT
Putting Iron Ore's through-the-cycle earnings in perspective
Exhibit 1: Rio Tinto and BHP's pre-tax unlevered FCF per tonne (EBITDA-Capex) in Real Terms between 2002- 2025e
Source: Morgan Stanley Research estimates (e), Company Data. BHP financials displayed in CY periods

Fears of what comes after the peak. Amid persistent worries about a "post- peak China" steel world, Iron Ore prices have remained relatively resilient - exceeding most market expectations for 2025. Nonetheless, that resilience has not translated into above- normal economics: five years of sharp cost inflation have materially reset operating and replacement costs, so on a real basis unlevered (pre- tax) FCF per tonne for the majors (BHP/RIO) is running below its long- run average - even when the 2008- 11 super- cycle is excluded. Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
